records.text: Can I just say...Steam has ZERO security or well might as well be zero on it's own. So I've been busy learning about game cracking and it's literally this simple with steam.Assuming the game has no DRM (stuff which stops you from playing the game without owning it) other than checking for steam and checking if the user owns the game on steam all that's required is:1. Patch "steam_api64.dll" specific to the steam appid of the game2. Enjoy your cracked gameYeah...and that's if you do it YOURSELF. It takes even less to just pickup a steam_api64.dll from steamunlocked.com, modify the config with your game's appid and gg.Probably under 2 minutes....

records.text: Writing a language is hard. Not the actual coding part but streamlining it into an efficient process. For example, I'll be writing the call function evaluator because a function might be passed an argument from a call function. Then I'd realize there's no function evaluator, then classes need functions to be a class. As well as hierarchy of evaluation, for example evaluate strings first, ints first, etc. It's pretty much a mess of patching this, adding hacky support for one feature that one evaluator uses then updating it for all evaluators to use them while determining hierarchy in a logical manner. Don't get me wrong though it's a very fun project to learn from, it's just a lot of work that sometimes feels overwhelming.What's everyone else up to?

records.text: List of IOS presentations/videos/links with a brief description as a pin for me:0x41con(2023):Blacktop - Anatomy of lockdown mode (https://github.com/blacktop/presentations/blob/main/0x41con_2023/PDF/AnatomyOfLockdownMode.pdf) Very descriptive and in depth!Saagarjha - All work and no play makes jack a dull boy (https://github.com/saagarjha/Presentations/blob/main/0x41con%202023/0x41con2023.pdf) A pretty nice dive into a security perspective on swift playgroundsOpa334:0x41con(2024) - Modern Jailbreaking Techniques (https://github.com/opa334/Presentations/blob/main/0x41con%20-%20Modern%20Jailbreaking%20Techniques.pdf) A very understandable presentation on how jailbreaking is nowZer0con(2024)- How to jailbreak ios 16(https://github.com/opa334/Presentations/blob/main/Zer0Con%202024%20-%20How%20to%20Jailbreak%20iOS%2016.pdf) Amazing insight from the developer of dopamine himself.Siguza:https://blog.siguza.net/ enough said: his posts are very well written and wryly entertaining as wellQwertyuiop:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8mQAYeozl5I Life and death of an IOS hacker attacker (hexacon 2022) A fun thrilling presentationhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SVUrFlwP-t0 One weird trick the securerom hates (video presentation based on pdf below)Checkra1n:https://assets.checkra.in/pdf/oneweirdtrick.pdf the whole foundation for the checkm8 exploitBlackbird:https://github.com/windknown/presentations/blob/master/Attack_Secure_Boot_of_SEP.pdf Presentation on a SEP bugA Silicon Bug in Apple's a7 SoC v2:https://github.com/Proteas/a7-sep-bug/blob/main/A%20Silicon%20Bug%20in%20Apple's%20A7%20SoC-v2.pdf A very long, very technical deep dive into a SEP bugMosec 2023 Baijucon - https://github.com/pattern-f/presentations/blob/master/Write-a-SEP-app-for-iOS.pdf by pattern-f. A cool and honestly pretty different style from most presentationsFugu15- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rPTifU1lG7Q Linus Henze is amazingUntethering ios 11:A good but old presentation by littlelailo: https://media.ccc.de/v/36c3-11034-tales_of_old_untethering_ios_11Mach-O format:Demystify Mach-o: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S9FFzsF0aIA Operation triangulation (2023) - What You Get When Attack iPhones of Researchers: https://media.ccc.de/v/37c3-11859-operation_triangulation_what_you_get_when_attack_iphones_of_researchers#t=255 Interesting, epic and amazing.OffensiveCon2023:MacDirtyCow – Auditing and Exploiting XNU Virtual Memory (Ian Beer): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jrxOhGGxDZ8OffensiveCon2024:Thomas Roth (Ace up the sleeve) - https://youtu.be/QlaJQEa3_zQ Ian Beer (Blasting past webp) - https://youtu.be/ZawX9I9MM6YQuentin Meffre (Escaping the Safari Sandbox) - https://youtu.be/sFsllHllXssKFD:Felix-pb's write-up for the superbug he found: https://github.com/felix-pb/kfd/tree/main/writeupsA whole bunch of presentations from offensivecon24 I have yet to watchThat's all I can remember for now, I'll update it based on when I find new resources. Feel free to check these out

records.text: To clarify on my previous post about js:The reason why security is non-existent on js is due to it being a client-side language. Essentially, your browser acts like a mailbox queueing webpage "X", "Y" etc... to it's Javascript runtime. From there the Javascript is then compiled and executed FROM YOUR DEVICE. Meaning most security checks aside from obfuscation are useless. Take a normal flask server for instance:@app.route("myroute")def myroute():  # process data here  return dataThere's no actual way to find out for sure what processing happened unless the source is public or you have a good guess how it's used because the only part actually executed on device is the returned data. Meanwhile, on vanilla js, the processing happens via the on device file. It's kinda like a paradox. How are you supposed to secure your file when it has to be decrypted or ran somehow. Right now, as far as I know minified js is a good form of obfuscation. One other similar issue is api-based requests. For example, while processing the data the server might make a request to "https://xyz.com" and you would be unable to know. However with js, you can simply do this:It genuinely is that easy to trace requests via js. A more popular example would be twitter's broadcasts. Simply go to any broadcast, search '.m3u8' in the network panel and you'll see direct links which can be utilized to download the broadcast from. (The example is from a malicious site known as "iremovalra1n")

records.text: Writing a language is hard. Not the actual coding part but streamlining it into an efficient process. For example, I'll be writing the call function evaluator because a function might be passed an argument from a call function. Then I'd realize there's no function evaluator, then classes need functions to be a class. As well as hierarchy of evaluation, for example evaluate strings first, ints first, etc. It's pretty much a mess of patching this, adding hacky support for one feature that one evaluator uses then updating it for all evaluators to use them while determining hierarchy in a logical manner. Don't get me wrong though it's a very fun project to learn from, it's just a lot of work that sometimes feels overwhelming.What's everyone else up to?

records.text: List of IOS presentations/videos/links with a brief description as a pin for me:0x41con(2023):Blacktop - Anatomy of lockdown mode (https://github.com/blacktop/presentations/blob/main/0x41con_2023/PDF/AnatomyOfLockdownMode.pdf) Very descriptive and in depth!Saagarjha - All work and no play makes jack a dull boy (https://github.com/saagarjha/Presentations/blob/main/0x41con%202023/0x41con2023.pdf) A pretty nice dive into a security perspective on swift playgroundsOpa334:0x41con(2024) - Modern Jailbreaking Techniques (https://github.com/opa334/Presentations/blob/main/0x41con%20-%20Modern%20Jailbreaking%20Techniques.pdf) A very understandable presentation on how jailbreaking is nowZer0con(2024)- How to jailbreak ios 16(https://github.com/opa334/Presentations/blob/main/Zer0Con%202024%20-%20How%20to%20Jailbreak%20iOS%2016.pdf) Amazing insight from the developer of dopamine himself.Siguza:https://blog.siguza.net/ enough said: his posts are very well written and wryly entertaining as wellQwertyuiop:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8mQAYeozl5I Life and death of an IOS hacker attacker (hexacon 2022) A fun thrilling presentationhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SVUrFlwP-t0 One weird trick the securerom hates (video presentation based on pdf below)Checkra1n:https://assets.checkra.in/pdf/oneweirdtrick.pdf the whole foundation for the checkm8 exploitBlackbird:https://github.com/windknown/presentations/blob/master/Attack_Secure_Boot_of_SEP.pdf Presentation on a SEP bugA Silicon Bug in Apple's a7 SoC v2:https://github.com/Proteas/a7-sep-bug/blob/main/A%20Silicon%20Bug%20in%20Apple's%20A7%20SoC-v2.pdf A very long, very technical deep dive into a SEP bugMosec 2023 Baijucon - https://github.com/pattern-f/presentations/blob/master/Write-a-SEP-app-for-iOS.pdf by pattern-f. A cool and honestly pretty different style from most presentationsFugu15- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rPTifU1lG7Q Linus Henze is amazingUntethering ios 11:A good but old presentation by littlelailo: https://media.ccc.de/v/36c3-11034-tales_of_old_untethering_ios_11Mach-O format:Demystify Mach-o: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S9FFzsF0aIA Operation triangulation (2023) - What You Get When Attack iPhones of Researchers: https://media.ccc.de/v/37c3-11859-operation_triangulation_what_you_get_when_attack_iphones_of_researchers#t=255 Interesting, epic and amazing.OffensiveCon2023:MacDirtyCow – Auditing and Exploiting XNU Virtual Memory (Ian Beer): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jrxOhGGxDZ8OffensiveCon2024:Thomas Roth (Ace up the sleeve) - https://youtu.be/QlaJQEa3_zQ Ian Beer (Blasting past webp) - https://youtu.be/ZawX9I9MM6YQuentin Meffre (Escaping the Safari Sandbox) - https://youtu.be/sFsllHllXssKFD:Felix-pb's write-up for the superbug he found: https://github.com/felix-pb/kfd/tree/main/writeupsA whole bunch of presentations from offensivecon24 I have yet to watchThat's all I can remember for now, I'll update it based on when I find new resources. records.text: To clarify on my previous post about js:The reason why security is non-existent on js is due to it being a client-side language. Essentially, your browser acts like a mailbox queueing webpage "X", "Y" etc... to it's Javascript runtime. From there the Javascript is then compiled and executed FROM YOUR DEVICE. Meaning most security checks aside from obfuscation are useless. Take a normal flask server for instance:@app.route("myroute")def myroute():  # process data here  return dataThere's no actual way to find out for sure what processing happened unless the source is public or you have a good guess how it's used because the only part actually executed on device is the returned data. Meanwhile, on vanilla js, the processing happens via the on device file. It's kinda like a paradox. How are you supposed to secure your file when it has to be decrypted or ran somehow. Right now, as far as I know minified js is a good form of obfuscation. One other similar issue is api-based requests. For example, while processing the data the server might make a request to "https://xyz.com" and you would be unable to know. However with js, you can simply do this:It genuinely is that easy to trace requests via js. A more popular example would be twitter's broadcasts. Simply go to any broadcast, search '.m3u8' in the network panel and you'll see direct links which can be utilized to download the broadcast from. (The example is from a malicious site known as "iremovalra1n")

records.text: Writing a language is hard. Not the actual coding part but streamlining it into an efficient process. For example, I'll be writing the call function evaluator because a function might be passed an argument from a call function. Then I'd realize there's no function evaluator, then classes need functions to be a class. As well as hierarchy of evaluation, for example evaluate strings first, ints first, etc. It's pretty much a mess of patching this, adding hacky support for one feature that one evaluator uses then updating it for all evaluators to use them while determining hierarchy in a logical manner. Don't get me wrong though it's a very fun project to learn from, it's just a lot of work that sometimes feels overwhelming.What's everyone else up to?

records.text: List of IOS presentations/videos/links with a brief description as a pin for me:0x41con(2023):Blacktop - Anatomy of lockdown mode (https://github.com/blacktop/presentations/blob/main/0x41con_2023/PDF/AnatomyOfLockdownMode.pdf) Very descriptive and in depth!Saagarjha - All work and no play makes jack a dull boy (https://github.com/saagarjha/Presentations/blob/main/0x41con%202023/0x41con2023.pdf) A pretty nice dive into a security perspective on swift playgroundsOpa334:0x41con(2024) - Modern Jailbreaking Techniques (https://github.com/opa334/Presentations/blob/main/0x41con%20-%20Modern%20Jailbreaking%20Techniques.pdf) A very understandable presentation on how jailbreaking is nowZer0con(2024)- How to jailbreak ios 16(https://github.com/opa334/Presentations/blob/main/Zer0Con%202024%20-%20How%20to%20Jailbreak%20iOS%2016.pdf) Amazing insight from the developer of dopamine himself.Siguza:https://blog.siguza.net/ enough said: his posts are very well written and wryly entertaining as wellQwertyuiop:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8mQAYeozl5I Life and death of an IOS hacker attacker (hexacon 2022) A fun thrilling presentationhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SVUrFlwP-t0 One weird trick the securerom hates (video presentation based on pdf below)Checkra1n:https://assets.checkra.in/pdf/oneweirdtrick.pdf the whole foundation for the checkm8 exploitBlackbird:https://github.com/windknown/presentations/blob/master/Attack_Secure_Boot_of_SEP.pdf Presentation on a SEP bugA Silicon Bug in Apple's a7 SoC v2:https://github.com/Proteas/a7-sep-bug/blob/main/A%20Silicon%20Bug%20in%20Apple's%20A7%20SoC-v2.pdf A very long, very technical deep dive into a SEP bugMosec 2023 Baijucon - https://github.com/pattern-f/presentations/blob/master/Write-a-SEP-app-for-iOS.pdf by pattern-f. A cool and honestly pretty different style from most presentationsFugu15- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rPTifU1lG7Q Linus Henze is amazingUntethering ios 11:A good but old presentation by littlelailo: https://media.ccc.de/v/36c3-11034-tales_of_old_untethering_ios_11Mach-O format:Demystify Mach-o: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S9FFzsF0aIA Operation triangulation (2023) - What You Get When Attack iPhones of Researchers: https://media.ccc.de/v/37c3-11859-operation_triangulation_what_you_get_when_attack_iphones_of_researchers#t=255 Interesting, epic and amazing.OffensiveCon2023:MacDirtyCow – Auditing and Exploiting XNU Virtual Memory (Ian Beer): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jrxOhGGxDZ8OffensiveCon2024:Thomas Roth (Ace up the sleeve) - https://youtu.be/QlaJQEa3_zQ Ian Beer (Blasting past webp) - https://youtu.be/ZawX9I9MM6YQuentin Meffre (Escaping the Safari Sandbox) - https://youtu.be/sFsllHllXssKFD:Felix-pb's write-up for the superbug he found: https://github.com/felix-pb/kfd/tree/main/writeupsA whole bunch of presentations from offensivecon24 I have yet to watchThat's all I can remember for now, I'll update it based on when I find new resources. Feel free to check these out

records.text: To clarify on my previous post about js:The reason why security is non-existent on js is due to it being a client-side language. Essentially, your browser acts like a mailbox queueing webpage "X", "Y" etc... to it's Javascript runtime. From there the Javascript is then compiled and executed FROM YOUR DEVICE. Meaning most security checks aside from obfuscation are useless. Take a normal flask server for instance:@app.route("myroute")def myroute():  # process data here  return dataThere's no actual way to find out for sure what processing happened unless the source is public or you have a good guess how it's used because the only part actually executed on device is the returned data. Meanwhile, on vanilla js, the processing happens via the on device file. It's kinda like a paradox. How are you supposed to secure your file when it has to be decrypted or ran somehow. Right now, as far as I know minified js is a good form of obfuscation. One other similar issue is api-based requests. For example, while processing the data the server might make a request to "https://xyz.com" and you would be unable to know. However with js, you can simply do this:It genuinely is that easy to trace requests via js. A more popular example would be twitter's broadcasts. Simply go to any broadcast, search '.m3u8' in the network panel and you'll see direct links which can be utilized to download the broadcast from. (The example is from a malicious site known as "iremovalra1n")

records.text: Writing a language is hard. Not the actual coding part but streamlining it into an efficient process. For example, I'll be writing the call function evaluator because a function might be passed an argument from a call function. Then I'd realize there's no function evaluator, then classes need functions to be a class. As well as hierarchy of evaluation, for example evaluate strings first, ints first, etc. It's pretty much a mess of patching this, adding hacky support for one feature that one evaluator uses then updating it for all evaluators to use them while determining hierarchy in a logical manner. Don't get me wrong though it's a very fun project to learn from, it's just a lot of work that sometimes feels overwhelming.What's everyone else up to?

records.text: List of IOS presentations/videos/links with a brief description as a pin for me:0x41con(2023):Blacktop - Anatomy of lockdown mode (https://github.com/blacktop/presentations/blob/main/0x41con_2023/PDF/AnatomyOfLockdownMode.pdf) Very descriptive and in depth!Saagarjha - All work and no play makes jack a dull boy (https://github.com/saagarjha/Presentations/blob/main/0x41con%202023/0x41con2023.pdf) A pretty nice dive into a security perspective on swift playgroundsOpa334:0x41con(2024) - Modern Jailbreaking Techniques (https://github.com/opa334/Presentations/blob/main/0x41con%20-%20Modern%20Jailbreaking%20Techniques.pdf) A very understandable presentation on how jailbreaking is nowZer0con(2024)- How to jailbreak ios 16(https://github.com/opa334/Presentations/blob/main/Zer0Con%202024%20-%20How%20to%20Jailbreak%20iOS%2016.pdf) Amazing insight from the developer of dopamine himself.Siguza:https://blog.siguza.net/ enough said: his posts are very well written and wryly entertaining as wellQwertyuiop:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8mQAYeozl5I Life and death of an IOS hacker attacker (hexacon 2022) A fun thrilling presentationhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SVUrFlwP-t0 One weird trick the securerom hates (video presentation based on pdf below)Checkra1n:https://assets.checkra.in/pdf/oneweirdtrick.pdf the whole foundation for the checkm8 exploitBlackbird:https://github.com/windknown/presentations/blob/master/Attack_Secure_Boot_of_SEP.pdf Presentation on a SEP bugA Silicon Bug in Apple's a7 SoC v2:https://github.com/Proteas/a7-sep-bug/blob/main/A%20Silicon%20Bug%20in%20Apple's%20A7%20SoC-v2.pdf A very long, very technical deep dive into a SEP bugMosec 2023 Baijucon - https://github.com/pattern-f/presentations/blob/master/Write-a-SEP-app-for-iOS.pdf by pattern-f. A cool and honestly pretty different style from most presentationsFugu15- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rPTifU1lG7Q Linus Henze is amazingUntethering ios 11:A good but old presentation by littlelailo: https://media.ccc.de/v/36c3-11034-tales_of_old_untethering_ios_11Mach-O format:Demystify Mach-o: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S9FFzsF0aIA Operation triangulation (2023) - What You Get When Attack iPhones of Researchers: https://media.ccc.de/v/37c3-11859-operation_triangulation_what_you_get_when_attack_iphones_of_researchers#t=255 Interesting, epic and amazing.OffensiveCon2023:MacDirtyCow – Auditing and Exploiting XNU Virtual Memory (Ian Beer): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jrxOhGGxDZ8OffensiveCon2024:Thomas Roth (Ace up the sleeve) - https://youtu.be/QlaJQEa3_zQ Ian Beer (Blasting past webp) - https://youtu.be/ZawX9I9MM6YQuentin Meffre (Escaping the Safari Sandbox) - https://youtu.be/sFsllHllXssKFD:Felix-pb's write-up for the superbug he found: https://github.com/felix-pb/kfd/tree/main/writeupsA whole bunch of presentations from offensivecon24 I have yet to watchThat's all I can remember for now, I'll update it based on when I find new resources. records.text: To clarify on my previous post about js:The reason why security is non-existent on js is due to it being a client-side language. Essentially, your browser acts like a mailbox queueing webpage "X", "Y" etc... to it's Javascript runtime. From there the Javascript is then compiled and executed FROM YOUR DEVICE. Meaning most security checks aside from obfuscation are useless. Take a normal flask server for instance:@app.route("myroute")def myroute():  # process data here  return dataThere's no actual way to find out for sure what processing happened unless the source is public or you have a good guess how it's used because the only part actually executed on device is the returned data. Meanwhile, on vanilla js, the processing happens via the on device file. It's kinda like a paradox. How are you supposed to secure your file when it has to be decrypted or ran somehow. Right now, as far as I know minified js is a good form of obfuscation. One other similar issue is api-based requests. For example, while processing the data the server might make a request to "https://xyz.com" and you would be unable to know. However with js, you can simply do this:It genuinely is that easy to trace requests via js. A more popular example would be twitter's broadcasts. Simply go to any broadcast, search '.m3u8' in the network panel and you'll see direct links which can be utilized to download the broadcast from. (The example is from a malicious site known as "iremovalra1n")
